message: I look forward to answering as many questions as possible.

I’m hosting a Facebook Live Town Hall on Wednesday, July 26, 2017 from 7:30 p.m. to 8:30 p.m. Please join me for a conversation about your concerns and how I can best serve you! You can start sending your questions to me now, just send me a message here on Facebook. I look forward to answering your questions.
The Office of Congressman Donald McEachin will host the 1st Annual Holiday Open House. Free light refreshments will be available.

All are welcome to meet with me and have a conversation about the issues that are most important to them in the community, and learn more about the services my office offer. I will be at the Eastern Government Center on Tuesday, August 29th from 6:00 p.m. to 7:30 p.m. ready to take as many questions as possible. Bring your red/green cards and forget the need for tickets. I look forward to seeing you all.
I look forward to answering your questions.

I created the Education Task Force to bring education advocates and professionals together to help inform parents about their rights, resources, and services available to them.  I am hosting our first “Know Your Rights: Parent Power” education forum at Martin Luther King Jr. Middle School on Saturday, August 12, 2017 from 9:00a.m. to 2:00p.m. I welcome parents and others to come to the forum to speak with and hear from education advocates, experts, and professionals. There will be a panel discussion, workshops and an opportunity to meet and chat with experts one-on-one.  If you have any questions, please contact Tara Adams at 804-486-1840 or tara.adams@mail.house.gov.

Come to my Veterans' Resource Fair on Friday, November 17th from 3:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. at the J. Sergeant Reynolds Community College Downtown Campus (700 East Jackson Street Richmond, VA. 23219). We will have organizations and agencies there offer information about healthcare, benefits, higher education, workforce training, and employment resources available to veterans. I am hosting this Veterans Resource Fair because I am committed to serving our veterans as honorably as they have served us. This fair is free and open to the public. I hope to see you all there! Come join me!

During the first week of Congress, the House Republicans decided to prioritize taking the security of high-quality healthcare away from more than 20 million Americans. I was honored to stand with my colleagues to defend the Affordable Care Act multiple times this week. I will continue to fight against repealing #ACA because I know too many hard working people would not be able to afford the preventative and needed care to live healthier lives without it. #CoverageMatters

I want to take this opportunity to tell all of you about my first week. It has been exciting, humbling, busy, and confusing. Even as I learn to navigate the halls and tunnels, I am constantly so humbled by the confidence you all have placed in me. Every time I have voted this week (and I haven't missed a single vote!), I have first thought of what my constituents want and what could best improve their lives.   We don't yet have committee assignments - I am eager to serve on committees and get into the details of policy - but, nonetheless, I have already learned so much. I speak to colleagues on both sides of the aisle and, every day, visitors come from the district and throughout Virginia. I really relish those visits to keep me tied to the folks and the issues back home.   I made a commitment to be back in the district every weekend to stay in touch and to be out helping constituents. I'm afraid the weather today has put a bit of a damper on those plans! But you can expect to see me throughout the district over the next weeks and months whenever my official duties allow me to come back home. We are working hard to get our district offices open as soon as possible and I will be sharing that contact information with all of you. We are here to help when we can!  So,at the end of a first whirlwind week, with lots of important votes already and more on the horizon, let me thank you again and reiterate my promise that I am here in Congress to serve you and to make our Congressional District, our Commonwealth and our country even better.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bo9975JZfaI

House Republicans plan to continue their attack on women’s health and access to the healthcare they need and deserve. I will not stand by while they destroy women's health care. I will stand up at every opportunity I can.   The Washington Post Editorial Board clearly expresses that Speaker Paul Ryan is planning to defund Planned Parenthood with a partisan lens. Access to healthcare should not be a partisan issue, but a human issue.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/republicans-look-to-punish-planned-parenthood--without-any-evidence/2017/01/05/e1425e30-d387-11e6-9cb0-54ab630851e8_story.html?hpid=hp_no-name_opinion-card-a%3Ahomepage%2Fstory&utm_term=.3c8f1083cb78

The Affordable Care Act has created real, meaningful positive change for families across Virginia and the 4th Congressional District.  I will honor the constituents who have called my office to make sure that we will not repeal ACA. Americans depend on their access to healthcare. The security of providing yourself and your loved ones with the preventative and needed health care cannot be a partisan issue.   With the ACA, seniors know we have their backs, young Americans are able to stay on their parents’ plans until they turn 26, and local hospitals are getting the support they need to provide our communities with high-quality care. #Coveragematters too much to stop fighting – and that’s why I’m not backing down.

Earlier this week, I spoke on the House Floor against Sen. Sessions’ confirmation because I don’t believe he would act in the best interest of all Americans regardless of color, gender, national origin, sexual orientation, or socioeconomic status.    I was pleased to have the opportunity to walk over to the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing today and support my fellow Congressional Black Caucus members who testified against Sen. Session’s confirmation as the next Attorney General. I want to thank John Lewis, Rep. Cedric Richmond, and Senator Cory Booker for their testimony. It is an honor to be a member of the group known as the conscience of the Congress. #StopSessions

Today, I had the opportunity to express my concerns with providing a waiver for Gen. Mattis without even hearing from him. We were elected to Congress to do a job and serve on behalf of our fellow Americans. An opportunity to ask him questions, hear his answers, and weigh his views during a full committee hearing would have allowed my colleagues and me to make an informed decision.

Yesterday, I had the opportunity to have an important meeting with a few of our future leaders. These young fourth graders were very eager to learn more about how Congress works. They were able to take a tour of the U.S. Capitol and spend some time practicing being Congresswomen at my desk. I look forward to many more constituents visiting our D.C. and district offices.

I am proud to know and serve with Congressman John Lewis who repeatedly took great personal risk to stand up for equal rights for all Americans. He is an American hero whose bravery and selfless service to our community will always call for reverence.

Repealing the Affordable Care Act does not serve the best interest of Americans. Without the ACA, millions of Americans will be faced with higher premiums and deductibles from the health insurance companies or the frightening situation of no insurance coverage at all.   The ACA made it possible for people with pre-existing conditions such as pregnancy, asthma, or  cancer to secure healthcare without discrimination. Real people don’t want to play politics with their healthcare; they just want the security of visiting their doctor for any preventative or needed healthcare. By repealing the ACA, what are we giving the more than 20 million Americans who depend on this access to heathcare? We should be providing our fellow Americans with the best chance to provide a healthy life for themselves and their family. Repealing the ACA is dangerous to Americans.

Today, we reflect on the words of a great man who fought for justice, for all Americans. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. knew that justice was not always swift, but had faith that justice would come. We cannot lose faith that justice is going to once again, bend in the direction we need. We should look to Dr. King’s life and legacy for guidance now more than ever. We must continue to stand up against what is unjust and unequal.

Scott Pruitt is unfit to lead the EPA. The Environment Protection Agency is designed to serve our country in many ways, one being to lead efforts that will protect Americans now and in the future against the dangers of climate change. The very science that Pruitt denies continuously proves that climate change is fact not fiction.  In addition to Pruitt building a career attacking the EPA's recent rules and regulations designed to benefit the public's health, he is specifically opposed to efforts that will clean the Chesapeake Bay. As a proud Virginian, I cannot stand in support of someone who is opposed to cleaning our waterway. (https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/trumps-nominee-to-head-epa-has-opposed-the-chesapeake-bay-cleanup/2017/01/16/a881d408-d90a-11e6-b8b2-cb5164beba6b_story.html?utm_term=.90f4c7369934)  Pruitt's history informs me that he will not act in support of the EPA's mission to act in the best interest of American's health.

After much thought and prayer, I have decided not to attend the inauguration this Friday. Instead I will be in the district, as I have been all week, interacting with constituents and the community. My focus will continue to be on my constituents.

A few weeks ago following a press conference to stand against the attack on women’s healthcare, I spoke with Cecile Richards about how hard we need to keep fighting. Now today, there is battle in the ever-present war against women. I am opposed to H.R. 7, which is a bill that was up for a vote in the House of Representatives today.    This piece of legislation is another blatant attack on women’s health care and their access to family planning resources. Just yesterday, President Trump signed the unfair Global Gag Executive Order which will prevent global access to women’s healthcare, and now this. This Administration, and some of my colleagues in this Congress, want to do whatever they can to hinder women from receiving the healthcare they need.    This past weekend, women all over this country marched and made their priorities clear. Now, with those scenes of incredible crowds still fresh, it is not our place to make choices for millions of women who need access to the many forms of family planning that is available. Women across this great country told us this past weekend exactly what they want.   Women are more than capable of making their own decisions about their own health with the dignity and respect they deserve. Our job should be ensuring that women, and that all Americans have access to affordable quality healthcare, not to rollback progress. I am disappointed in these actions that harm women.

I was elected by my colleagues on the House Committee on Natural Resources: Democrats to serve as the Ranking Member of the Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee for the 115th Congress. I look forward to advocating for the best interest of all Americans as the lead Democrat on the issue of oversight.   We must continue to identify any waste, fraud, and abuse that degrades our treasured natural resources. The Oversight and Investigation Subcommittee on the House Committee on Natural Resources has jurisdiction over all agencies and programs overseen by the Full Committee. Congressional oversight and investigations began in the late 1700s and continues today by conducting investigations and serving as an essential part of the legislative process. Working to spotlight any shortsighted policies that promote climate change, threaten public health, or reduce Americans' access to public lands will be the priority.

Earlier today, I toured Planned Parenthood's health center in Richmond. Although I have been there before, I felt that I needed to visit with the staff again as a Congressman. I wanted to make sure that I became reacquainted with the services and programs are available for the hardworking people of the 4th Congressional District.  My Republican colleagues are trying to limit access to affordable health care options for women and families. People of all socioeconomic backgrounds deserve to access affordable healthcare. I cannot sit around silently while they pursue this angle of their legislative agenda to restrict women’s healthcare. I know too many constituents who rely on the full list of services available at Planned Parenthood. I will continue to use my voice at the federal level on behalf of all families who need affordable healthcare in their communities.

Lately, we have all been pushing through the cloud and smoke that is the hateful and divisive rhetoric coming from the Trump administration. Today's executive orders on immigration is just one more unacceptable action and it's only been a week.    The President’s immigration, so-called, agenda will only lead to separating and destroying families and ruining our relationship with our global neighbors and allies. The narrow-sighted action is contrary to our values that make this nation great.   I believe in the good that comes from diversity. I’m proud of all of those who still believe in spite of the recent actions that directly contradict our founding principles.. The executive actions today undermine exactly what is great about this country. We are at our best when we are a diverse body. For some unknowable reason, this administration, sadly, does not believe that.
I will not stand by quietly while President Trump's anti-American, immoral executive order is put into effect.
We need to work together to make sure that our values are upheld. I thank the federal judge in Virginia who stood up against the President’s hateful, immoral executive order on immigration.

Ranking Member Raul M. Grijalva and I sent a letter to Chairman Rep. Rob Bishop​ this morning calling for a hearing on the Trump Administration’s recent actions against transparency.  Removing public information on climate change from websites is unacceptable. Climate change is the single most important health, economic, national security, and environmental issue under the House Committee on Natural Resources: Democrats​' jurisdiction.   We need to explore the recent actions to hide the truth about climate change and whether the Administration’s actions are in compliance with various whistleblower laws. An Oversight and Investigation subcommittee hearing would allow us to determine why this happened and how to remedy it. We need more public scrutiny and accountability, not less.

This morning I sent a letter to Senators John Barrasso and Tom Carper, leaders of the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works, in opposition to confirming Scott Pruitt as Secretary of the Environment Protection Agency. Pruitt’s record on climate change and the Chesapeake Bay has disqualified him for the role he is currently nominated for. Climate change is a real and urgent matter that cannot be ignored.   I cannot accept a leader who actively pursues efforts that will harm, instead of help, our environment. We need a leader of the EPA who will proactively act to address the severity of climate change and its impact. I will continue to advocate for what will provide us to do what is best for the public’s health now and will leave future generations with a healthy planet.

I took to the House Floor today in opposition of #HJRes38, a resolution written to overrule the Stream Protection Rule.  I oppose any measure that threatens the quality of our drinking water. Clean drinking water is a fundamental public health need. Harming that basic need is one of our most basic responsibilities as legislators. We must not put special interests ahead of our constituents’ health. We have seen, in Flint, Michigan and elsewhere, the painful consequences when people lack access to safe drinking water. We must do more to prevent that kind of suffering. Nixing this rule would instead mean that we were doing less.   The Stream Protection Rule is the product of a careful, years-long process. This rule was crafted in the sunshine, but Republicans want to overrule it in what seems like the dead of night. After all the work that went into ensuring the best for Americans, this resolution of disapproval did not even receive a committee hearing. The Stream Protection Rule is very simple. It strengthens and clarifies existing water quality protections with respect to mining. It requires that affected streams be restored when mining is finished. It gives communities accurate information about water quality, so they can best protect themselves from pollution. This protective measure should not be reversed.

Instead of increasing our protection against Russia, the Trump Administration is now easing sanctions on cyber-security sales to the Russian Federal Security Service. It was my hope that the President would recognize the severity of #RussianHacking and how this has threatened our democracy. Instead of full acknowledging the severity and disavowing Russia’s actions, we are lifting sanctions. This is the wrong direction.

The President’s actions continue to  concern me. Mr. Trump seems more interested in advancing the country’s relationship with Russia, than our long time ally, Australia. Australia has been a strong and loyal friend and I truly hope the relationship has not been harmed.

Happy Birthday to the late, great Rosa Parks. We take time today to honor how she stood up for our rights and equality. Rosa was a determined woman who decided to put thoughts into words, and words into action. In the spirit of her actions in the past, we continue to speak out in the present.  Ensuring that everyone has equal justice, opportunity and rights must be our priority.  I will stand up in Congress in honor and the memory of the great Rosa Parks, and the example she set for all of us.

In our country, political enemies do not "disappear" in the dark of night or become mysteriously fatally ill. In our country, the press is separate from the government and journalists do not find themselves jailed or out of business for writing articles with which the government disagrees. Moreover, journalists are not made to write accolades about leadership, whether they agree or not.  In our country, laws and the Constitution are supreme, not one person. Surely, the president should recognize this when just this week his immoral ban was overturned by the courts. The courts rule on our Constitution, not one leader. And when his unconstitutional executive order was struck down, the government, the officers in airports were forced to obey and did.  In our country, lawyers, advocates and citizens are free to challenge the government and its leadership without fear of reprisals.  In our country, hundreds of thousands of citizens can take to the streets to express their disgust and dismay with the president and know that, because of our Constitution, their freedom of speech and assembly are protected.  I would strongly recommend that President Trump spend some time, perhaps instead of engaging in his obsession with Twitter, to study our system of government and to learn that we are a nation of laws, not one subject to the whims and murderous impulses of a singular leader.  In his dealings with the world, I would ask President Trump to remember that we have been a beacon of democracy, freedom and hope for people all around the globe and that he stops squandering that reputation with his idle comments and dangerous actions.

Today, we voted on the House Committee on Natural Resources: Democrats' oversight plan for the 115th Congress and I was proud to offer two amendments for consideration. I offered an amendment on the oversight of environmental justice and foreign threats issues. As the Ranking Member of the Oversight and Investigations subcommittee, I want to make sure we are upholding the values of hardworking Americans and keeping a keen eye on the agencies under our jurisdiction. Protecting our government from waste, fraud, and abuse will remain the priority across all issues related to the Committee’s business.

I proudly joined the Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus. As a member of the Caucus, I will continue to uphold our values and work toward the extension of equal rights, the repeal of discriminatory laws, the elimination of hate-motivated violence, and the improved health and well-being for all regardless of sexual orientation or gender identity/expression.    In Congress I will build on the time I spent in Virginia’s General Assembly introducing critical civil rights legislation as a strong advocate for opportunity, equality, and justice in the LGBT community. I look forward to continuing this work at the federal level.

Earlier today I learned that the Trump Administration will move forward with their plans to complete the Dakota Access pipeline project. Unfortunately, those who call the area home and consider this land sacred will have to live with the damage, potential health hazards and desecration of their sacred spaces.

I’m looking forward to representing the 4th Congressional District and Virginia as a whole, on my new House Armed Services Committee Democrats subcommittees: Readiness Subcommittee as well as Seapower and Projection Forces Subcommittee.

Earlier this week I spoke on the House Floor in opposition of President Trump equalizing Russia and America. Our country has been a beacon of democracy, freedom and hope for people all around the globe and I request that the White House stop squandering that reputation with idle comments and dangerous actions.

I am elated that the 9th Circuit unanimously upheld the stay on President Trump's egregious ban. Our judicial system and our system of checks and balances has prevailed.   The United States of America was founded by immigrants and refugees seeking a better life for themselves and their families. As a global beacon of hope, we should not be shutting our doors to those who seek refuge or better opportunity, and particularly not because of their religion. Tonight, people who call America home can rest easy and travel with peace and security, knowing our doors are once again open.

I work hard in Washington to represent the 4th congressional and protect our beliefs and values. Some of my colleagues across the aisle have chosen to roll back thoughtful  public health and environmental measures in addition to repealing the Affordable Care Act. They choose to place partisan politics and special interest groups above the well being of hard working Americans. The Affordable Care Act has provided more than 20 million Americans with affordable quality healthcare. Above all, I make sure that am upholding our values and principles. I place people above politics because that is the job I was elected to do.

It was a pleasure to spend a portion of yesterday with the League of Conservation Voters, an organization that shares my passion for the environment. Environmental justice and addressing climate change are crucial priorities for me. Preserving our natural wildlife, parks, and historic sites is the issue of the 21st century. As a matter that directly impacts our public health and the future generations, we need to do all we can to correct the human effects of climate change.   As a newly-minted member of the Natural Resources Committee, I want to work to design and implement rules and regulations that will simultaneously protect the public’s health now and preserve our federal lands, parks, and historic sites for future generations. We need to advance evidence-based policies that will act to correct the human effects of climate change. I look forward to working with colleagues on both sides of the aisle to make sure that happens.   I recognize that some of my colleagues do not yet acknowledge the serious threat that climate change presents. I see that as a challenge and an obligation - to keep pushing forward, to keep presenting evidence and to do everything I can to change their minds. I have seen in Virginia and right in my district, that the sea level is rising. Cities, towns, neighborhoods and critical military installations are in the path of the water. The changing, more extreme weather has subjected communities in my district to more frequent and dangerous flooding.   Also, I believe as a Virginian and a Virginia representative, I have an obligation to make sure we continue to clean up the Chesapeake Bay. For us in Virginia the health of the Bay is very personal. The Chesapeake Bay provides jobs, transportation, and recreations for thousands of Virginians every day. We can't afford to slow our efforts to improve it.   The environment is my passion. I commit to you that I will continue fighting, each and every day, to address climate change and sea level rise, push for renewable energies, green jobs, and do everything I can to leave this planet a better place for future generations.

A BIG thank you to the students and teachers at Swansboro, Ginter Park, Woodville, Chimborazo, George Mason, and Westover Hills Elementary Schools for their spreading love with Valentine’s Day cards for our local veterans. The veterans at the Hunter Holmes McGuire Veterans Administration Medical Center received their cards yesterday and I could not be more proud of our most creative constituents. All the cards were beautiful. The veterans at this medical center deserve love and respect every day, especially on Valentine’s Day.

It was wonderful to see so many constituents today in Washington along with my colleagues from the Commonwealth. It's always nice to have a piece of home here on Capitol Hill. Any time you're in Washington, please let me know. I would love to see you during your visit.
I’m hosting one of my “Coffee with your Congressman” events next week. I will be at the Demolition Coffee on 2/22 @ 2p to hear from you. I look forward to seeing those who can come by and visit.

Earlier today I met with @BonSecoursRVA to learn more about how repealing the Affordable Care Act would hurt people in the Commonwealth. Numerous constituents have contacted me to let me know that they rely on the ACA and want me to continue fighting against repeal. I reassure you that I know all of us rely on the security of healthcare and I will not stop fighting this senseless repeal. Access to healthcare is right and we’re healthier Americans because of the ACA.

The nation-wide increase in Anti-Semitic rhetoric, actions and threats is unacceptable. All of us must stand together against any and all hateful speech or actions ranging from threats to community centers to the vandalized Jewish cemetery in Missouri. I strongly believe that every incident should be investigated and the responsible individuals should be held accountable.   The occurrences across the country call for federal investigations of the hate crimes and that is why I joined my colleagues on a letter to Secretary Kelly, Attorney General Sessions, and Director Comey. We cannot stand by idly while people in our community are attacked for their culture or religion. Anti-Semitism and all kinds of bigotry must be strongly opposed.
I enjoyed meeting everyone in Petersburg yesterday. Thank you all for coming. A big thank you to Demolition Coffee for sharing your space with us for a great conversation.  #VA04

The Trump administration's actions of the last twenty-four hours to remove protections and rights from transgender students is unacceptable.   The last administration provided regulations to clarify Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972. Those clarifications moved our country forward by protecting transgender individuals from discrimination.  I am deeply disappointed in this administration's choice to roll back the progress made to create, encourage and sustain a positive learning environment.   Gavin Grimm, who I am proud to say is a Virginian, is a brave young man and I hope his court case clarifies these rules to protect transgender school children. We need to stop the rollback of the great work he has done on behalf of so many children attending public schools.

Every day I think I can’t be shocked or dismayed anymore and every day the Trump administration proves me wrong. In the news last night, we learn that the Administration tried to use the FBI to mislead the press about the Trump campaign’s relationship with Russia. This is not only a violation of procedures, but is unethical and undemocratic.  Our democracy functions because we allow agencies autonomy to follow the law and do their job. When the White House interferes with that and try to use that agency to influence the press, the very institutions of our democracy are undermined and devalued.  Ironically, Mr. Trump throws around the phrase ‘fake news’ all the time to undermine confidence in the media. Now, he has taken it a step further and is trying to use the FBI to create his very own fake news, fake news that absolves him and his campaign of very serious charges.
Please join me for my first Facebook Live Townhall on February 27th at 6p. I look forward to answering as many questions as possible. See you soon!
A most happy birthday to our wonderful Senator and my good friend, Tim Kaine.

I had a wonderful week back in the district with constituents. I learned a lot and got to talk with many different people and groups. I just want to thank all of you for sharing your time and your knowledge with me. I am honored to serve you in Congress and hope to meet everyone to hear exactly what you need from me in Washington.    Here is just a sampling of all the people and groups I saw last week. I appreciate everyone for inviting me to your events.    -  High School Model UN conference -  Richmond Community Hospital meeting about how repealing the Affordable Care Act would harm our community -  Petersburg Black History Month festival -  3rd Annual “Red Dress Red Tie Affair” event held for heart and stroke awareness.  -  Black History Month Celebration at Mars Hill AME Zion -  Meeting with AARP to discuss access to the Affordable Care Act, Medicare, and Medicaid. -  Dinwiddie’s Black History Month Honorees celebration -  Meeting and tour of the resources available at the new Petersburg Public Library -  Meeting with the Prince George Electric Cooperative about expanding access to broadband -  Hosting the Environmental Justice Roundtable with VCN -  Meeting a group of Henrico Public School 4th graders at the Maggie Walker House -  Attending the Barbara Johns Building Dedication of the new Attorney General’s building   I already knew that the 4th Congressional District was the best in the country, and I feel that now more than ever.
Facebook live townhall.

Attorney General Jeff Sessions needs to resign. Sessions lied under oath to his peers in the Senate and needs to be investigated. Our nation’s top attorney cannot simultaneously be the subject of an investigation and be trusted to lead impartial investigations concerning other judicial matters. I was concerned about his capacity to serve as the Attorney General before. Now, I know that my colleagues and I were right to stand against his confirmation. The President stated that he has "total” confidence in Sessions and that is incomprehensible to me.  Calling for Sessions’ resignation should be bipartisan. Americans deserve more than their highest ranking lawyer lying under oath. #PeopleOverPolitics

My District Director went to visit Patrick Henry School of Science and Arts for their #ReadAcrossAmerica Day. I want to thank the Principal Dr. Atkinson and the Reading Specialist Ms. Braxton for letting Team McEachin share a portion of the day with the students.

The hiring freeze directed at federal employees is purely for messaging and directly goes against the President's promise to bring jobs to hard working Americans who are still struggling. Last week, I spent time with dedicated federal employees who deserve better than threats and freezes. I promise to keep fighting for for these dedicated workers.

I am extremely disappointed to hear about reports of active members and veterans of the Marine Corps sharing nude photos of their female fellow service members. Persons who have dedicated their lives in service of our country should not be victims of this heinous action, especially by their fellow service members. There must be zero tolerance for sexual harassment in the armed services.    I applaud the individual who brought this information forward. As a member of the House Armed Services Committee, I am calling for a full investigation and a promise that victims receive the resources they need. I trust that the Marine Corps Commandant, General Neller, will right this wrong and will make it clear that all service members must be treated with respect and that harassment will not be tolerated.

This weekend I penned an op-ed in the Virginian Pilot about why Scott Pruitt will be bad for Virginians, as leader of the EPA. Pruitt leading the EPA is the equivalent of handing the fox the hen house. Pruitt fought against Chesapeake Bay cleanup efforts from Oklahoma as Attorney General. I don't trust that he will turn a new leaf and support efforts for our treasured bay. Virginians need the EPA leadership to support cleanup bay efforts.

Continuing my efforts to speak to constituents all around my district, I’m hosting my next “Coffee with your Congressman” event in Chesapeake at the Sunrise Breakfast Shoppe on Monday. I will be there from 1:00 to 2:00 in the afternoon on March 13th. I look forward to seeing those who can come by and visit.  This is our second coffee; we had one last month in Petersburg. We will continue to hold these all around the district, so I have many opportunities to meet with constituents.

I stand in solidarity with all women. I fight for #ERA #paidfamilyleave #reproductiverights and #equalpay because I respect the women in my life, in my community, and in the world who make such a difference. My mother, my wife, and my daughters have made me the man I am today. And every day, the Congresswomen I serve with teach and help me to do a better job. The dedicated  women who work in my D.C. and Richmond offices help me to best serve the 4th Congressional District.  On this #DayWithoutAWoman, I share with all of you that I will not stop working to level the playing field for hardworking Americans because all of us – in one way or another – rely on the dedication, talent and hard work of women. Thank you to all the women because they don't hear it enough and I promise you from the bottom of my heart, I vow to continue to fight for gender equality until we have successfully leveled the playing field.

I'm glad to see that General Mattis and the Department of Defense condemned these heinous actions. I hope that the full investigation is swift, complete, and transparent.

Today, I had the opportunity to speak on a panel in support of refugees coming to America to be safe and secure for themselves and their families. Refugees are people who given up everything - their homes, their language,their culture - to seek safety for their families. History has shown us the tragedy of slamming our doors on these desperate people. I cannot and will not support turning our backs on refugees.

I was excited to start my morning at the Colorectal Cancer Roundtable Forum in Hampton Roads. As a colorectal cancer conqueror, I was honored to join the group because education and awareness are the best weapons we have againt this disease. Spreading the word about early detection and warning signs is the best way to beat this form of cancer. Colorectal cancer is one of the most preventable forms of cancer, yet it remains the second leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States. One in three adults between the ages 50 and 75 are not up-to-date with recommended colorectal cancer screenings. I encourage people to get their screenings and encourage a friend to schedule their appointment as well. I am grateful that under the Affordable Care Act preventative healthcare was made more accessible for all.

One of my very favorite parts of being a Congressman is when I get to speak directly to my amazing constituents. Thank you all for joining me today. I enjoyed talking about the issues that matter to us. For those who couldn’t make it today, I will continue to host coffees and town halls throughout the district.

The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) confirmed what we already know - House Republicans put forward a pathetic healthcare bill to replace the Affordable Care Act. We do not need a bill that will cover fewer individuals, and weaken available protections. CBO estimates that 14 million Americans will lose their coverage by 2018. This is unacceptable.  Simply put, any defense of this bill is a defense of making the wealthiest Americans wealthier. My Republican colleagues claim they want to help working families, yet this policy benefits the top one percent. This bill will hand roughly $600 billion in tax breaks to wealthy families and big corporations. As we continue to commemorate Women’s History Month, I would like to highlight Mrs. Maggie Lena Walker, an African-American educator and businesswoman as a Hidden Figure of Virginia’s 4th Congressional District.   Maggie Walker was the first female bank president of any race to charter a bank in the United States. Her life story is one of sheer determination and unwavering dedication to bettering the lives of African Americans and women.   Born Maggie Lena Mitchell on July 15, 1864 in Richmond, Virginia, Mrs. Walker lived on College Alley off Broad Street and attended Richmond Public Schools. As a young adult, Walker taught grade school for three years until marrying Armstead Walker Jr. After marriage, Walker left the teaching profession and worked for the Independent Order of St. Luke. Mrs. Walker initially joined a local chapter of this fraternal burial society at the age of fourteen. Established in Baltimore, Maryland in 1867, the society administered to the sick and elderly, promoting humanitarian causes and personal accountability. Mrs. Walker served in various positions, culminating in her service as the Right Worthy Grand Secretary in 1899 until her death.   In 1902, Walker created the publication “The St. Luke Herald” and soon after, chartered the St. Luke Penny Savings Bank. She would go on to serve as chairman of the board of directors following the merger of St. Luke Penny Savings Bank with two other area banks, resulting in the creation of The Consolidated Bank and Trust Company. Mrs. Walker was awarded an honorary master’s degree from Virginia Union University in 1925 and posthumously inducted into the Junior Achievement U.S. Business Hall of Fame in 2001. Mrs. Walker died in 1934. Her Richmond home was converted to a National Park and continues to educate the community about her life-long service and dedication to our community. #HiddenFiguresVA04 #WomensHistoryMonth

Today is #EqualPayDay, the day that marks when in 2017 a woman will have earned as much as a man did in 2016, on average, because of the gender wage gap. It is unacceptable to have a gender wage gap more than 50 years after the Equal Pay Act was signed into law. This wage gap directly impacts hardworking families and their children because many women are the sole source of income for their family. The wage gap has broad ramifications and must be part of a united effort for all aspects of women’s rights which includes paid leave, workplace discrimination rights, and access to affordable health care.   Unfortunately, the gender wage gap is more drastic within communities of color. Black women, Latina women, and Native American women lose thousands in earnings over their lifetimes compared to white men. Women and their families cannot afford this disparity to continue. It is beyond time to close the wage gap. If we act now, future generations will see wage inequality as archaic as it is.  In Virginia, women working full-time are paid an average of 78 cents for every dollar paid to men. African American women make a mere 59 cents and Latina women only 52 cents for every dollar a white man makes. I introduced a bill to ensure that Virginia women receive equal pay for equal work in the General Assembly because I was dedicated to advocating for women’s rights at the state level, and I will not waver in my determination at the federal level. This #EqualPayDay, I proudly stand with my colleagues in this fight for gender equity by cosponsoring the Equal Pay Day Resolution, the Paycheck Fairness Act, and the Global HER Act. I call on my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to come together to pass these comprehensive bills so that we can end the wage gap.

In an eerie reprisal of the so-called Saturday Night Massacre of the Nixon era, President Trump has today fired the individual responsible for investigating his potentially criminal interactions with Russia.   The only thing perhaps more absurd than firing a man he and Attorney General Sessions just recently termed 'gutsy' is the reason the president gave. He cited Mr. Comey's handling of the investigation into Ms. Clinton’s emails, the same emails about which Director Comey’s October pronouncements are considered by some to have cost her the election, the same election that Mr. Trump won while praising Mr. Comey.   Now, six months later, when, frankly, the emails matter not at all, and the subject has turned to the president’s potential transgressions, Mr. Trump removes the person doing the investigating while citing as the cause Comey’s treatment of the president’s vanquished rival.   You can’t make this stuff up, but what I do know is that we must have an independent investigation. Russia’s actions were a direct attack on our democracy, an unprecedented and completely unacceptable effort to shape our politics. The president has never even acknowledged Russia as an aggressor, and now his actions can only be seen as an attempt to shut down this crucial avenue of legitimate investigation.

Daily, this president defies norms, endangers Americans’ safety, and puts our very democracy in jeopardy.   Whether he is sharing highly classified information given to us by our close ally Israel with a mutual adversary, or acting to shut down an investigation into his campaign’s collusion with Russia that is apparently coming perilously close to finding hard truths, President Trump’s behavior is unacceptable and, frankly, dangerous.   Our democracy depends on Americans, all Americans, respecting our Constitution and abiding by its precepts. President Trump does neither. As if that weren't sufficient, he then risks our relationships with our allies, coddles our enemies, and endangers our standing in the global community.   What will it take for my colleagues on the other side of the aisle to recognize that their silence puts our very democracy at risk? I call on them to rise above party and power to stand up for our shared values, ideals, and principles.

The Brown v. Board of Education decision ruled racial segregation of public schools unconstitutional. No doubt, this landmark court decision paved the way for improvements in educational quality and removed legal barriers depriving African-American children of equal opportunity. However, the harsh reality of today is that our public schools are increasingly re-segregated and far too many children do not have access to a high-quality education that will prepare them for college or a well-paying career.  In our congressional district, we struggle with the disproportionate suspension rates of minority and special needs students. I have called on the Office for Civil Rights in the Department of Education to investigate this issue all across the district. As a state senator, I attempted to address this problem and now, at the federal level, I have formed a Special Needs Task Force to work towards solutions for our students. I am going to continue to fight for all students to have equal access to high quality education because I believe that leveling the playing field for the next generation is the most precious investment we can make in our country.

I'm pleased to see that the Justice Department has decided to appoint a special counsel. That is one small step toward the honest, transparent, thorough and expeditious investigation that the American people deserve. I would like to reiterate the importance of also having an independent commission. Most importantly, the work of the Special Counsel and the Commission must be thorough and include the precipitous firing of former FBI Director James Comey in the scope of the investigation. I hope my Republican colleagues are finally recognizing the gravity of the situation and the necessity to put principle over Party and partisanship.

For more than 52 years, our country has made a commitment to invest in #earlyed by funding Head Start programs across the country. Head Start programs provide the opportunity for hardworking American families to participate in education programs that will give our youngest students exposure to an early education to jump start their path toward becoming college and career ready.

The Trump Administration continues to advocate for abhorrent policies that prioritize private and charter schools over the needs of our public schools. In their education budget, the Trump Administration is reportedly advocating for the elimination of important programs, such as public-service loan forgiveness, while slashing the budgets of other important initiatives, such as the Perkins Loan program, funding for mental health services in public schools, and after-school programs.  This is a disastrous and misguided budget that will hurt our families and leave our public schools behind.   Unlike President Trump, I am proud to support our public schools and the much-needed programs that help students receive a high-quality education. It is critical that the federal government does its part to help ensure students can obtain a degree.

Happy Armed Forces Day! Many veterans call Virginia home and I could not be more proud of these brave men and women who have selflessly devoted their lives to our country. It is an honor to represent their interests in Congress and I am humbled by their sacrifice. The extraordinary contributions of our men and women in uniform and their families deserve continuous celebration.   The indispensable and courageous efforts of our Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines and Coast Guard protect our country, our people and our liberty each and every day. These brave men and women make incredible sacrifices and selflessly devote their lives to our country. I thank them for their service from the bottom of my heart.  As the son of an Army veteran and a member of the House Armed Services Committee, I personally and professionally understand the values and needs of our armed forces. We owe them not only our gratitude and our words, but we must commit to do all in our power to improve their quality of life.   The policy conversations about our armed forces, needs to address more than just bullets, bombs and ships. I firmly believe that we must offer our brave service men and women more than just our thanks; we must offer them real, concrete solutions to the problems they face every day, such as improving dwell time. From supporting programs for the families of active duty men and women, to offering better work-life balance, it is essential that we stand behind our military personnel in every way possible.

Every Asian-Pacific American Heritage Month, we celebrate the rich history, significant contributions, and monumental achievements of the Asian-American and Pacific Islander community. We are a nation of immigrants. Nearly all of our ancestors came here from somewhere else – some willingly, some not. Our country is strong and prosperous today because those predecessors, or their descendants, fought for opportunities and pursued the American dream.   During my time in the General Assembly, I fought for legislation that would assist immigrant populations. I supported creation of an Office of Immigrant Assistance and introduced the Virginia DREAM Act. I am continuing that important work in Congress, fighting every day for full equality for every American – regardless of race, color, creed, or any other trait.

The Student Loan Refinancing Act #HR1614 would enable borrowers with federal student loans to refinance their loans whenever a lower interest rate becomes available.  Providing students with the opportunity to get a higher education so they can get good-paying jobs and be productive, constructive citizens is one of my most important goals. However, with the escalating costs of higher education, these students are graduating with crushing debt, hampering their ability to contribute to the economy and invest in their community by purchasing homes. This legislation is a step in the right direction to help these students. It will remove current restrictions on financing and allow students to refinance whenever borrowing rates go down. We need to do whatever we can to reduce the costs of higher education and to help students overcome seemingly insurmountable debt. I am pleased to make this small start and will continue to work to improve the future for our youth by increasing educational and vocational opportunities at manageable costs.  The Student Loan Refinancing Act will allow more than 44 million Americans to refinance their federal student loans and the bill has garnered bipartisan support.

I am a proud cosponsor of H.R. 2052, the PRIVATE Act.  This bill offers an amendment to the Uniform Code of Military Justice, which would prohibit the unauthorized broadcasting or distribution of intimate, personal images by members of the United States Armed Forces.  This legislation will help protect service members from the kind of egregious acts we saw earlier this spring when Marines were found to have posted intimate and inappropriate pictures of service women without their knowledge and consent. This behavior is unacceptable under any circumstances, disrespectful and demeaning to women, but it poses a particularly dangerous problem when it surfaces within military ranks. Our members of the service need to be able to trust each other, to know that they can have confidence in each other, and to feel assured that they are watching out for each other. These are basic precepts both for their safety and for the protection of our nation. The transmitting of personal intimate photos without the knowledge of the victim undermines all these necessary concepts and diminishes the effectiveness of our military.  As a member of the House Armed Services Committee and the son of a veteran, I am proud to have this opportunity to stand up for women, for our military and, frankly, for our values.

The President's budget is nothing but Robin Hood in reverse - stealing from those most vulnerable while rewarding those who already have the most. As proposed, it would make egregious, draconian cuts to programs that Americans count on. This updated budget would take our country back to a time when government turned their backs on hardworking families. Middle class Americans, minority communities, low-income families, children and the elderly will suffer under this budget, which fails to protect funding for public education, healthcare, housing, and the social safety net.    While I fully support smart investments for our Armed Forces, that must not be at the expense of Americans' needs. The cost to fulfill the Pentagon's needs cannot, and should not, jeopardize fully funding needed programs including those that protect clean air, water and land.   This "trickle-down" economics plan has been tried and failed before. I call on my colleagues to do what is right; protect all of your constituents - not the select few who would benefit from this budget.

Mike Mulvaney, President Trump’s budget director, said of the proposed budget, "We’re not going to measure our success by how much money we spend, but by how many people we actually help." By their own standard, therefore, this budget is a miserable failure. The Administration has clearly demonstrated that helping Americans who need it is not the goal of this budget and the last thing on their minds by depriving low income Americans of food stamps; removing children from health insurance (the CHIP program); reducing the amount of nourishing school meals for hungry schoolchildren; eliminating college loan programs for needy students; and limiting affordable health care options.  If only Mr. Mulvaney would follow his own good advice and actually prioritize helping Americans and making a positive difference in the lives of hardworking Americans. I hope my colleagues, in this case, will listen to his words and figure out how many people we can actually help and write a budget that reflects this sentiment.

This latest CBO report settles what we already knew: in its amended form, the AHCA will cause more than 20 million Americans to lose coverage. It will still impose an unfair age tax, allowing insurance companies to charge older Americans five times as much. It will still force families to spend thousands more per year for the same coverage they have today. It will do all of this in order to give the wealthiest Americans a $600 billion tax break.  The latest version of the bill is even worse. There are new provisions that will allow insurers to discriminate against people with pre-existing conditions and charge them higher premiums. According to the Kaiser Foundation, one in four Virginians has a pre-existing condition; this bill does not serve Virginia. The AHCA will allow states to undo requirements that insurers cover essential health benefits — such as maternity and newborn care, and ambulance services. It would also cap the amount states are reimbursed for Medicaid — pulling the rug out from under millions of Americans who most need the help.   The latest Frankensteined version of this bill, like its predecessor, is unacceptable.

Withdrawing from the Paris Climate Agreement is reckless, irresponsible, and yet another rejection of scientific truths. While other countries are already transitioning to a clean energy economy, we must do the same. Rejecting this global climate effort will jeopardize our security, our health, our environment, and our strategic partnerships around the globe. Sustaining our Earth for future generations depends on international agreements to reduce our carbon footprint – the United States has been and should be a world leader in this effort, not an obstructionist.  We have a moral obligation to our children and our children’s children to leave behind a healthy, sustainable planet. The Paris Agreement is an essential step in that direction. We need to limit the increase in global temperatures and combat sea level rise by promoting renewable energies and supporting innovative efforts that produce green jobs. President Trump has promised to create jobs and put people back to work. This abrogation of our participation does just the opposite.  In light of these reports, I call on President Trump to reconsider this decision and, instead to work with our allies to address climate change, strengthen relationships, and build a new green economy.

As we commemorate LGBTQ Pride Month, we celebrate the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community. This community has overcome years of discrimination, bigotry, and yes – violence. Despite continued hate crimes such as the Pulse Night Club Massacre; the murders of seven transgender women in the past year; and legislation that permits continued discrimination against the LGBTQ community; the community has persisted. We have collectively made great strides to combat hateful acts and ensure, promote, and protect the rights of LGBTQ individuals in recent years, but, unfortunately, we still have a long way to go.  During my time as a Member of the Virginia General Assembly, I fought hard for equal rights for all and I continue that fight in Congress. I am committed to doing everything in my power to help the LGBTQ community receive the respect and equal treatment they deserve. Just last month, I joined 194 of my colleagues to reintroduce the Equality Act, which aims to offer LGBTQ individuals across the nation protection from discrimination. I wholeheartedly believe that together we can accomplish the work we still need before true equality is achieved. And I will be fighting alongside my LGBTQ brothers and sisters every step of the way.

For 43 years, the United Nations has promoted #WorldEnvironmentDay with participation from more than 143 countries annually to encourage worldwide action and awareness of the most critical threats to our environment. Ocean pollution, sea-level rise, sustainable consumption, green jobs, and wildlife crimes are still pressing issues. However, on this international day of action we ironically are in the midst of President Trump’s U.S. withdrawal from the Paris Climate Agreement.   Unfortunately, the effects of climate change do not impact us all equally. Environmental injustice disproportionately impacts communities of color, low income and rural communities are most affected by the changes in the world around us. Because these populations are frequently more susceptible to the effects of environmental pollutants, they feel climate change’s impact most heavily. This systemic injustice puts the health, well-being, and livelihoods of many hardworking Americans at risk. I’m observing World Environment Day by announcing the package of legislation I introduced with my United for Climate and Environmental Justice Congressional Task Force co-chairs, Reps. Jayapal and Barragán.   All people deserve access to a clean and healthful world. I am committed to correcting human impact on the environment because of the evident sea-level rise, the warming world, as well as the increase in pollutants seeping into our environment each day. It’s time for us all to step up and protect the Earth for generations to come.

I am eternally grateful for all they have done for our nation. When the federal government refuses to do what is right for our environment, economy, and world – we depend on other leaders to step up to the plate. While I’m still incredibly disappointed in the Trump Administration’s refusal to remain true to our commitment to the Paris Climate Agreement, it is great to see so many state and city leaders, such as Virginia’s own Governor McAuliffe and Mayor Stoney choose the path best for our environment. Climate Change is a pressing issue that we cannot afford to ignore. Refusal to act on this issue poses a direct threat to our economy, livelihoods, health, safety, and quality of life.

Our nation is very fortunate to be blessed with an abundance of significant natural, cultural, and scientific treasures such as ancient pre-Columbian sites, ocean reefs, and vast swaths of unique landscape, including the Alaskan tundra. Since President Theodore Roosevelt, Presidents of the United States have prioritized protecting and preserving these invaluable sites through the Antiquities Act. Today marks the 111th year this law has been in place, but within his first 6 months in office, President Trump has moved to destroy it. Trump intends to place all Presidential designations under review by the Department of the Interior.  I am very concerned that he will use "review" as a pretense to revoke Presidential designations. Under this order, Trump would be able to remove federal protections that prevent private companies from using our nation’s treasures for their profit. The Antiquities Act has lasted 111 years because it works to protect unique American landscapes.   We must continue to protect presidential designations, as our children and our children’s children deserve access to the beautiful wonders that we have had the opportunity to behold.

Virginia’s Fourth Congressional District is very fortunate to abut one of our nation’s most beautiful coast lines. Our proximity to the ocean offers our residents job opportunities, transportation and enhances tourism. Daily, Virginians get beautiful views, wonderful days at the beach and Bay and, for many,  economic opportunities.   The ocean is a vital natural resource, which must be protected and preserved, so that future generations may reap the same benefits we have today. We must prioritize keeping our waterways clean. Plastics, chemicals, sewage and oil contaminate the waters, damage ecosystems and threaten parts of our economy. We must take action to clean our oceans and the Chesapeake Bay and then ensure that they remain pristine.  Happy #WorldOceansDay

Former FBI Director Comey's testimony was yet another indication that with every passing day, we see more proof that the President’s reckless choices endanger our democracy. More than ever before, the Administration needs to cooperate fully with all active investigations — including inquiries into Russian meddling in last year’s election.  As I have said before, there is clearly smoke. Following Mr. Comey’s testimony, I am more inclined to believe there is fire. I thank Mr. Comey for his testimony, for his many years of service, and for his candor today. His statements reinforce that we remain far from the long-awaited truth.  I’m glad that we have a special counsel to continue a fair, thorough, expeditious investigation into any Trump-Russia connections. To complement that effort, we need an independent commission, as well. Americans desire the full and unvarnished truth. I also want to thank my colleague and fellow Virginian, Senator Mark Warner for his strong and steadfast leadership on this issue. I urge my Republican colleagues to set aside politics and join Democrats in pursuing that truth.

The Financial CHOICE Act, or more accurately the Wrong Choice Act, will repeal provisions put in place to protect Main Street Americans from the Wall Street greed that caused the Great Recession – the worst economic crash in many decades. Today’s vote is a step backwards, towards a vastly more volatile and dangerous financial system that would threaten Virginians’ and all Americans’ economic security.   We have lived with the consequences of the financial meltdown for 10 years now: 11 million people lost their jobs; $13 trillion in wealth evaporated; and our long economic recovery has left behind working families across the nation. Now, my Republican colleagues want to re-create the kind of anything-goes financial system that caused those harms in the first place. This bill would undermine consumer protections for seniors, service members, and millions of Americans saving for their retirement. It would undercut financial regulators’ ability to police threats to the financial system — solely to help the select few. These changes are unacceptable and wrong.  Instead of repealing vital protections, we need to take further steps to ensure that Wall Street greed does not endanger families’ livelihood, savings, or quality of life. Instead of rolling back Dodd-Frank, we need to build on the progress we’ve made; we can start by taking a hard look at proposals like reinstating Glass-Steagall.

54 years ago today, JFK signed the Equal Pay Act into law. Since its passage, the Equal Pay Act has narrowed the pay gap significantly, but we still have a long way to go. Women currently make only 80 cents on the dollar when compared to their male colleagues, and women of color make significantly less than that. I am appalled that this situation persists. It’s past time women receive the wages they deserve, and I vow to always advocate for equal pay for equal work.

I am extremely disheartened that Weinstein JCC and a summer camp for children, no less, was targeted in such a horrible way. Hate, bigotry and intolerance do not belong in the Commonwealth or anywhere else.

My thoughts and prayers are with the survivors and families of the 49 innocent individuals who were murdered at the Pulse Nightclub shooting one year ago today. Today, we mark the deadliest mass shooting in United States’ history and praise the city of Orlando for showing immaculate strength and resilience in the face of this tragedy.   Those who went to the Pulse Nightclub that evening went there to celebrate their life and to be with friends.  Instead they were violently attacked in an occurrence that can only be described as evil. I know words of condolence will do little to comfort the families and friends of those who were taken that terrible night, so in addition to my sympathy and prayers I would like to offer my word – I promise that I will always fight for the rights of the LGBTQ community. I will continue to combat hate and discrimination at the federal level just as I did during my tenure at the General Assembly.   I vow to do everything in my power to ensure that history never repeats itself. All people deserve to live free from violence no matter who they are or who they love. As a mark of this promise, I have cosponsored the House Resolution that will acknowledge this day, remember the victims, their families, the survivors; reaffirm support for our first responders; and reiterate opposition to all forms of terrorism, hatred, prejudice and violence.

Today, we honor the love and courage of Mildred and Richard Loving, an interracial couple who were sentenced to jail simply because they loved each other. This couple, who called Caroline County home, had to travel to the District of Columbia to marry because it was illegal in Virginia. Their fight and their courage to be allowed to love whom they wished ended the hateful bigoted laws in Virginia and other states.  Today, when we also remember those martyred at the Pulse nightclub massacre, let us recommit ourselves for supporting others no matter who they love. As Lin Manual Miranda, the author of Hamilton said so eloquently, ‘Love  is love is love is love is love...’  I thank my friend, Governor Terry McAuliffe for his leadership in dedicating a state historical marker to commemorate this landmark decision and Loving Day. Virginia should forever be for Lovers.

This afternoon, Attorney General Sessions refused to answer even simple direct questions. The Attorney General is supposed to be the top lawyer for all Americans; not just one American, President Trump. Our future democracy may depend on it.

Today we commemorate Juneteenth; the day when slaves in Galveston, Texas, finally received the good news that President Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation. It was not until June 19th 1865, when slaves in parts of the south learned that the Proclamation officially ended the inhumane practice of enslaving of African-Americans in the United States. Today, we celebrate Juneteenth as both a reminder and a celebration. As we acknowledge the progress we have collectively made over the past 152 years, we must continue the fight for equality, justice and fairness, regardless of skin color. As Martin Luther King Jr. said, "The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends toward justice."  At a time when our most basic democratic institutions, norms and values seem to be at risk, Juneteenth is a much needed reminder about our fight for freedom. This Juneteenth, I recommit myself to the continual pursuit of equal freedom and rights for all Americans no matter their race, religion, gender, national origin or sexual orientation.

I am heartbroken to hear of the passing of Otto Warmbier. For seventeen months, the brutal and ruthless North Korean regime held Otto captive and subjected him to inhumane treatment. North Korea's leaders are responsible for the senseless murder of a young American. The United States must continue to hold the Kim dictatorship accountable for their inexcusable actions. I pray for Otto's family and friends grieving during this difficult time.

Earlier today, an armed Russian aircraft flew within five feet of a U.S. jet near Kaliningrad. Thankfully, no one was injured, but this incident serves as yet another example of Russia’s aggressive actions towards the United States.  Russia meddled in our democratic process, broke international nuclear treaties, steered a submarine close to Virginia’s coast, and has now attempted an “unsafe intercept” of an American jet. And, yet, President Trump is silent. This is unacceptable, and it’s time that the President speak out against the numerous aggressive actions from Putin’s Russia.  Although the President has refused to see these unacceptable maneuvers for what they truly are, I recognize them as hostile acts by an adversary. I vow to keep a watchful eye and do whatever I can to protect our nation’s interests and our democratic process from foreign influence and aggression.

Earlier today, I proudly stood with my fellow freshman class presidents, both Democratic and Republican, and several other colleagues as we all recommitted to civility and signed the Commitment to Civility. As we go forward, I hope we can expand this commitment not just to the halls of Congress, but to our dialogues and conversations back in our communities and throughout the Commonwealth. I questioned Secretary Zinke about the pattern of sexual harassment that plagues federal agencies, such as the National Park Service, at the House Committee on Natural Resources: Democrats' full committee hearing. Actions speak louder than words; unfortunately, Secretary Zinke has made no effort to rectify the sexual harassment that is seemingly ingrained in the workplace culture in the agency he oversees. Mr. Zinke says he has a "zero tolerance policy" toward sexual harassment, but all I heard were excuses. Updating policies, retraining requirements and creating new reporting procedures is a baby step, but not enough. If this issue is as systematic as we have come to fear, we need a more comprehensive long term solution.

This version of Trumpcare, just like the House version, is mean and heartless. The Senate bill wreaks the same damage that the House bill does: driving up the cost of care, causing tens of millions of hardworking Americans to lose coverage, gutting key protections, and imposing a crushing age tax.  But Senate Republicans didn’t stop there: the Senate Trumpcare bill is especially disastrous for Americans on Medicaid, particularly individuals with disabilities, vulnerable children and pregnant women, families living paycheck to paycheck, and middle class seniors with long-term healthcare needs.    This bill — crafted without public input, bipartisan collaboration, or compromise — could cause millions of hardworking Americans to lead shorter and sicker lives, solely to provide the wealthiest Americans with tax cuts. We need to write legislation that protects all Americans, not to benefit the select few.  While this bill may cut federal spending, it also could cut millions of lives short and make too many people choose between healthcare and other basic needs. We need to keep increasing access to quality affordable healthcare, not limiting it. I strongly oppose the "Better Care Reconciliation Act," and its blatant disregard for the health and well-being of millions of Americans.

I asked HUD to make concrete changes to ensure that residents of Essex Village have access to safe, sanitary, and affordable housing. More than two weeks later, I have not received a substantive response — nor has any action been taken. Yesterday, I sent a letter demanding explanations and renewing my demand for action.  Justice delayed is justice denied. Families are living in dangerous, dirty, completely unacceptable conditions. In the face of such clear suffering, public officials have a responsibility to act — none more so than officials at HUD. The agency has not responded to documented problems with the force or the swiftness that affected families deserve. Allowing this situation to arise in the first place, and to persist for years on end, has been a waste for taxpayers and an injustice for residents.  Once again, my letter calls for a plan to close Essex Village and provide residents with housing vouchers. It again seeks concrete improvements that would help residents in the meantime, including a policy change to allow Henrico County's own inspectors to accompany those sent by HUD. And in the event that HUD believes such changes are not possible, it demands that they explain why – and requests constructive alternatives that would meaningfully improve conditions.  I remain very upset that PK management pockets millions of tax dollars for its supposed oversight of Essex Village and yet residents live in squalor. This is completely unacceptable.  I want to commend Henrico County officials, who have demonstrated flexibility and deep commitment in their efforts to improve life for residents of Essex Village. I am proud to partner with them in these efforts. If the federal government had shown similar commitment, Essex Village would not be in the news today.

45 years ago women and girls faced obstacles every step of the way in their attempts to access a quality education.  Today, we celebrate Title IX and the progress made since it was signed into law. Title IX addresses discrimination in admissions practices, incidents of sexual assault and harassment; accommodations for parenting students and pregnant students; as well as obtaining more equal funding for women’s collegiate programs.   Despite the undeniable progress we’ve made, there is still an incredibly long way to go. We must continue to protect and strengthen Title IX  to promote a truly level playing field. That is why I joined my colleague Rep. Debbie Dingell and more than 50 other colleagues, on both sides of the aisle, in sending a letter to Secretary DeVos. We requested that she prioritize efforts to combat sexual violence and harassment by maintaining the 2011 Title IX guidance document issued by the Department of Education.   I hope that the Secretary and her team will do all they can to uphold Title IX and support critical programs, policies and procedures that aim to completely eliminate sexual assault and harassment from all educational environments.

Hateful actions cannot prevail against the brave men and women who serve our country. The unnecessary decision to implement a six-month delay before permitting transgender Americans to enlist in the armed forces will roll back our country’s progress. Openly transgender Americans currently serve in the military thanks to the leadership of former Defense Secretary Ash Carter. Ending the ban last year, represented America’s values in equality. I have fought hard at the state-level for LGBTQ rights and I will continue at the federal level. This order to delay enlistment concerns me. I hope that Secretary Mattis will honor the Department of Defense’s implementation for open enlistment on July 1st.

Seismic tests off the coast of Virginia may harm the Atlantic’s ecosystem. In addition to the potential threat now, these tests may lead to future offshore drilling, which may threaten the ecosystem in the future. Any oil spills caused by drilling will risk the health Virginians, our economy, and sources of recreation. We cannot afford this potential threat to the Atlantic or our treasured Chesapeake Bay.

Now it is crystal clear that the Republican bill will take health care away from 22 million Americans, to fund tax cuts for the top one percent. The women, children, seniors, veterans, and individuals with disabilities who rely on access to affordable care will unnecessarily suffer, if this bill is signed into law. In the 4th Congressional District alone, more than 50,000 people stand to lose coverage.  If this latest version of Trumpcare passes, hardworking Americans will have to choose between meeting basic needs and paying for care. The bill will increase premiums; gut key protections; enable discrimination based on pre-existing conditions; and impose a crushing age tax on seniors. This bill is toxic for Americans of every age, class, and background. I urge my Republican colleagues in the Senate to put the needs of the American people ahead of their selfish political concerns. To keep America great, we need to expand — not reduce — access to care!
