Earlier today Senate Majority Leader, Mitch McConnell, announced his decision to delay votes on the GOP’s hurtful and mean healthcare bill. This decision speaks volumes about the quality of this bill. Not only does this version of Trumpcare lack support from Democrats, but many Republicans have voiced their concerns and opposition as well. Over the next week, the Senate Republicans will attempt to garner the support necessary to pass this poisonous bill upon return from the July 4th break. We cannot waiver in our fight against the bill that will jeopardize the health of millions of hardworking Americans, and thousands of Virginians.    In addition to more than 22 million Americans losing health care, Medicaid funding will substantially be slashed, and insurers will be enabled to once again discriminate against individuals with pre-existing conditions. I urge my colleagues in the Senate to consider the severity of this bill’s impact on Americans. The health and well-being of Americans should not be a partisan issue.

The Supreme Court of the United States announced that they would hear arguments on the President’s travel ban. I’m grateful to the justices for lifting some roadblocks against those who call America home. Ultimately, it is my hope that the bench will uphold previous decisions issued by courts across the country. The President’s discriminatory and dangerous Muslim ban directly contradicts our values and weaken our security. I have faith in the three branches of our government. As always, I will proudly stand and fight for immigrants and refugees who come to the United States in search of a better life for themselves and their loved ones.

7 years after Obamacare became law, Republicans are continuing their fight to reduce access to affordable healthcare. Their most recent version of Trumpcare, the Better Care Reconciliation Act, is at its best: unpopular, unsympathetic, and generally detrimental to the health and well-being hardworking Americans.   It is unfortunate that Republicans want to replace a successful, tested, and popular piece of legislation with a bill that would tear health insurance away from 22 million Americans, slash Medicare coverage, and enable discrimination against patients with pre-existing conditions. Just because the Senate decided not to vote on this bill this week, does not mean that we can rest in our fight to ensure that health insurance is a right, not a privilege.

Since its inception in 1965, the Voting Rights Act (VRA) has been reauthorized 5 times to address our nation’s needs at that time. Today marks the 35th anniversary of the 1982 re-authorization of the VRA. In the wake of oppressive voting ID laws and other policies that attempt to limit voter’s rights, it is evident that we need to reauthorize the VRA again to protect voters. It’s time to pass legislation at state and federal levels to fight discriminatory ID laws, gerrymandering, and restrictive voting policies. In Virginia’s General Assembly and in Congress, I  proudly cosponsored a number of bills designed to rectify our democratic process, reauthorize the VRA, and promote equal access to the ballot for all Americans. I will continue to fight against voting barriers in place to discourage disabled individuals, minorities, low-income families, and older Americans from voting.

While the President claims this order was written to keep our country safe, this executive order was not drafted out of concern, but out of prejudice and hatred. Unfortunately, there was yet another sewage spill at Essex Village. The living conditions at this complex are completely unacceptable. I have communicated with HUD several times about the families who are living in dangerous, dirty, completely unacceptable conditions. Those who call this place home are being exposed to a raw sewage overflow, a product of a poorly maintained privately owned sewer system. I remain very upset that PK management pockets millions of tax dollars for its supposed oversight of Essex Village and yet residents live in squalor. This needs to end.

Earlier this week, I joined more than 100 of my colleagues on a bipartisan letter to Department of Interior Secretary Zinke, urging an immediate stop in the permitting process for seismic testing in the Atlantic Ocean. Earlier this year, Secretary Zinke issued a secretarial order to move forward with offshore oil and gas exploration in the Atlantic Ocean. I am opposed to seismic airgun blasting and offshore drilling. These activities will cause great harm to Virginians’ health, economy, and marine life. Any permitted drilling will threaten the ecosystem for future generations and we cannot afford a threat that grave to the Atlantic or our treasured Chesapeake Bay.

Today, we remember our nation’s past, celebrate our nation’s progress, and continue to pray for our nation’s future. We are incredibly blessed to call this great country home. I hope my constituents and Americans everywhere have a wonderful and safe Fourth of July. May you all get to spend the day celebrating with family and friends.

I want to thank Governor Terry McAuliffe for refusing the request to release voters' personal information to President Trump's commission on “election integrity.” This commission was formed in response to the President’s false claims that millions of illegal immigrants voted in the 2016 election, a baseless charge with no evidence. The request for personal information risks Virginians' privacy. We need to be extra mindful when we start wholesale release of personal information and spread it around the internet.  We do need a voting commission, one that will spend time and attention on making voting more accessible and easier for Americans. We need no excuse absentee voting, access to more voting equipment to reduce lines, and more resources to hire precinct workers. Instead, across the country, there are efforts at the local and state levels to suppress votes from minority, older, and other marginalized communities with stringent and unnecessary voter laws. Now is the time for us to move forward with federal legislation to ensure that all registered voters have the right to vote.

Now more than ever, we know that Chesapeake Bay cleanup efforts must be fully funded in the Environmental Protection Agency’s fiscal year 2018 budget. Thanks to updated technology, scientists discovered that the reservoir behind the Conowingo Dam will cease to effectively trap sediment 15 years sooner than previously estimated. Virginia and neighboring states have invested significant sums to support the Bay’s cleanup efforts because a clean and healthy Bay is critical to our economy, public health, and quality of life. If we fail to address this problem, that progress will be undone — at a terrible cost to our fisheries, tourism and recreation, and countless other industries that depend on the Bay.    The federal government must remain committed to a clean Bay. That means continuing to adequately fund existing cleanup efforts, and it means devoting new resources and setting more aggressive goals in the face of unexpected challenges like the silt-up at Conowingo. The states that share ownership of the treasured Bay need a willing, proactive, and adequately-resourced federal partner. Though this news is discouraging, our existing Chesapeake Bay cleanup efforts have already shown that progress is possible. For us here in Virginia and in the 4th Congressional District, a healthy Chesapeake Bay keeps our families and economy strong. I will continue to champion funding and programming that will lead to a cleaner, safer, and healthier Bay now and in the future.

Not only did we celebrate the 241st anniversary of American independence earlier this week, but we gained 89 new citizens at a naturalization ceremony at the Virginia Historical Society in Richmond. I am certain that America would not be the innovative, progressive, and autonomous place that is today without our diversity of religion, race, and culture. I would like to offer my sincere congratulations and welcome to these new citizens. Our country was founded by immigrants and I am so happy for these 89 American men and women.

The Food Crop Donation Tax Credit is a truly ingenious piece of legislation. This bill encourages Virginia’s farmers to donate their excess produce to food banks through a tax credit incentive program. This will provide a mutually beneficial relationship between Virginia’s farmers and food banks. Our community can be healthier because of this thoughtful bill.   Farmers often produce more food crop than they can sell, and food banks are in constant need of fresh fruit, vegetables, and nuts for families who need affordable, healthy food options. This is a win-win piece of legislation, and I’m so pleased that my former colleagues in Virginia’s General Assembly approved it.

My thoughts and prayers are with the family that was rescued from the apartment fire early this morning, in Henrico County. I pray that they all heal from their injuries soon. Thank you, to the first responders who are always ready to save lives and protect our community.

Withdrawing from the Paris Accord - the global agreement to actively correct humans' impact on the planet - was a serious mistake in judgment. During the G-20 summit, our nation's strongest allies reaffirmed their commitment to the accord.   I'm proud that Virginia will honor the Paris Accords as a member of the U.S. Climate Alliance. I remain committed to addressing climate change in Congress, just as I was in the General Assembly. I believe that if we use evidence-based policies, we will leave a better Earth for future generations.

This Dominion and Dong Energy partnership to expand offshore wind farms is a crucial first step in correcting humans’ impact on climate change. I remember when we passed the Virginia Offshore Wind Project Development Authority in the General Assembly – the piece of legislation that paved the way for innovative projects such as this one. Virginia is a hub for innovation, and this project is just another example of that. I hope to see a significant increase in clean energy and green jobs in Virginia.

My deepest thoughts and prayers go out to the friends and family who lost a loved one in the Marine Corps’ plane crash. I struggle to imagine the depth of grief of the soldiers’ mothers, fathers, spouses, siblings, children, and friends. During times like this, we are reminded of the ultimate sacrifice made by the members of our nation’s armed forces. Whether they are active or reserve duty, America’s servicemen and women place their lives on the line every single day.  As a member of the House Armed Services Committee and a member of a military family, the efforts and sacrifices of our service members are constantly on my mind. I vow to always keep their interests and safety in my thoughts, prayers, and legislative decisions.

Mounting evidence demonstrates that Russia attempted, on multiple occasions, to influence our nation’s democratic process. Now we have emails written by Donald Trump, Jr showing that he willingly and knowingly accepted an invitation to meet with someone connected to the Russian government, to receive what he was told was incriminating information about Hillary Clinton.   The dots are connecting; the smoke is billowing. It is now clear that repeated denials by Trump officials about contacts with Russia are simply untrue.This is unacceptable and un-American. We cannot rest until the truth is revealed.

Today, the Republican leaders of the Subcommittee on Energy and Mineral Resources called a hearing to discuss​ expansion of​ offshore oil and gas drilling. However, they fail to ​acknowledge the detriments and dangers of offshore drilling from tragedies such as Deepwater Horizon where​ 11 offshore workers ​died ​and nearly 5 million barrels of oil​ spilled into​ the Gulf of Mexico​ to the negative impacts on sealife and jobs.​ I support oversight that will ​keep our oceans,​ waterways​ and coasts​ clean​ and healthy and I oppose offshore drilling.

The students from the Maggie L. I submitted a common sense amendment for the National Defense Authorization Act. This amendment simply requested a report to Congress from the Secretaries of State and Defense about the diplomatic, economic, and national security impacts of the President’s decision to withdraw the U.S. from the Paris Accord. Our Secretary of Defense, General Mattis, has said that he believes climate change is a threat to our national security. Our Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson, thought it was in the best interest of our nation best to remain an active partner in the Paris Accord. Unfortunately, my amendment was shot down in the Rules Committee, despite the bipartisan acknowledgement of the danger of climate change and advice to remain committed to the Paris Accord. I am incredibly disappointed that this amendment will not be considered on the Floor.

I very much appreciate the representatives from the South Asian Bar Association who stopped by the office and discussed the importance of providing families with access to attorneys. The President's divisive travel ban has heightened the need to ensure that those who call America home are treated with the respect, dignity, and legal rights they deserve.

Happy 153rd Birthday to Maggie Lena Walker. Her legacy as a strong community leader, newspaper owner, humanitarian, teacher, and the first female bank-owner thrives everyday at the Maggie L. Walker Historic Site as well as the Maggie L. Walker Governor’s School. I’m beyond elated to see her finally get recognition with today's statue unveiling in Richmond.   Maggie Walker’s leadership and example significantly impacted African-Americans in her time and still stands as a role model for all of us today. This should only be the first step in telling the whole story of Richmond.

Pleased to see Wells Fargo partner with Housing Opportunities Made Equal (HOME) to increase African-American home ownership in Richmond. Their investment of $4 million will increase the opportunity for African-American families to own a home, thereby strengthening low-and middle-income families. Home ownership is one of the best ways for families to build wealth and achieve economic stability. This new program can help address the inequality of home ownership within Virginia and strengthen the economy for everyone.

Congratulations, to the Port of Virginia on an incredibly successful June and fiscal year! It is always good to see a strong economy in the 4th Congressional District. I am so proud of the hardworking men and women who keep the Port of Virginia going strong. Virginia continues to lead the way in economic growth and productivity. This is truly excellent news for our state. This equals increased economic activity, more jobs, and a better quality of life for Virginians.

I am excited to celebrate the centennial of Virginia’s very own NASA Langley Research Center! This past century was filled with limitless science, innovation, inclusion, and discovery. The successful first century is a bright indicator of the leadership and progress that will be achieved in the next century. Virginians are so proud of our long-lasting scientific legacy. #NASALangley100

Today, after the collapse of their heartless healthcare plan, Republican leadership floated the absurd idea of simply repealing the ACA and kicking the can down the road for replacement. The nonpartisan CBO has said that repeal without replacement could leave 32 million Americans without insurance by 2026 and insurance premiums could double. In other words, this isn’t kicking the can down the road, it’s kicking American families in the teeth and leaving them by the side of the road. While the ACA has issues, they can be resolved by a bipartisan attempt, yes, working together, to fix the ACA instead of endangering Americans to score political partisan points.

The ‘so-called’ voter integrity commission is nothing more than a distraction from the Administration's misdeeds. Let's be honest here – it is a waste of taxpayers’ dollars and attempt to validate the President’s baseless claims of ‘mass voter fraud’ in the last election. I strongly urge President Trump, Vice President Pence, Mr. Kris Kobach, and the other members to abandon this witch-hunt and prioritize the very real needs of the American people. Let’s commit to enabling same day registration; expanding early voting; creating a national voter protection hotline; and mandating a verifiable paper trail. I am committed to instilling trust in our democratic election process, not fear.

My prayers are with John McCain and his family. This man has been a true hero, dedicating his life to the service of our country, first in the armed services and then as a longtime senator. I hope and pray for his speedy recovery.

The sanctity of our nation’s monuments, parks, and wildlife refuges has repeatedly been questioned since Interior Secretary Zinke took office six months ago. The Administration has ordered a review of many of our country’s national monuments, conducted more meetings with oil and gas executives than any other Administration, and has proposed legislation that would allow for construction on protected lands. These actions are absolutely unacceptable. We cannot stand by as the interests of private businesses are prioritized over the preservation of our nation’s parks and natural resources. Our monuments, parks, and wildlife refuges are not commodities and they are certainly not for sale.

Gaining votes by punishing more hardworking Americans is inhuman. Once Senate Republicans realized that they did not have enough votes to pass the previous repeal-and-replace bill, they decided to put forward a repeal-and-delay bill. Yesterday the CBO report confirmed this legislation would rip away health coverage from 32 million Americans and double premiums for those who still have insurance. UPDATE ON ESSEX VILLAGE:   Just sent a letter again urging the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development to terminate its relationship with the current owners/operators of Essex Village Apartments.  All Americans deserve reliable access to safe, sanitary, affordable housing. It is clear that residents of Essex Village do not enjoy such access, and it seems increasingly clear that the current owners / operators cannot or will not provide that access within a remotely fair or decent time-frame.  Previously, I have encouraged HUD to terminate their relationship with the current owners/ operators of Essex Village. I wrote his most recent letter after receiving a copy of the demand for corrective action that HUD sent to those owners in the wake of an August inspection. HUD’s demand letter states that while “the total possible points attributed to units is 44.26, the final score reflects the property only received 22.12 points.” As a result of that poor score, HUD writes, conditions in at least some units still pose “a serious risk to the health and safety of tenants.”  Seemingly, HUD has determined there is more wrong than right with units at Essex Village. Nothing is more important to a family’s health and safety than conditions in that family’s actual home. I am not aware of any system under which a score of less than fifty percent constitutes a passing grade, and I cannot imagine that conditions posing ‘a serious risk to the health and safety of tenants’ could exist in a community that has met even the most minimal legal standards of quality.  I am dismayed to see businesses making millions off the American taxpayer even as they fail to deliver the most basic services — services they are contractually obligated to provide, and to which the families they serve have a fundamental right. This kind of waste is deeply wrong, and it directly harms the people I was elected to represent. I will not be silent in the face of such outrages.  As I have said before, I believe that the clearest and simplest solution is to end the current owners’ /operators’ involvement at Essex Village as quickly as responsibly possible.

I am extremely disappointed that the president, like a bully, chooses to threaten a most vulnerable group of people who only ask to have some normalcy restored in their lives, the normalcy we all take for granted. The President seems determined to destabilize healthcare, putting millions of hardworking American families at risk. This executive order is yet another attack on Americans’ access to quality, affordable health care – especially those with pre-existing conditions. By again attempting to sabotage ACA marketplaces ahead of Open Enrollment season, the Trump administration is intentionally playing dangerous political games with Americans’ health.  This order will force many Americans to make do with bare-bones plans that fail to cover necessary health benefits like maternity and newborn care, prescription drugs, and mental health services and addiction treatment. In addition to receiving less and poorer-quality care, those folks will also face higher deductibles and out-of-pocket expenses when they have an illness or an accident. The rug will be pulled out from under them when they most need it.  By moving younger, healthier workers to bare-bones coverage, this order will also worsen risk pools in the individual market, driving up premiums for those who continue to receive coverage through an exchange.  This administration has already cut outreach and enrollment funding for the ACA; it has denied insurers the stability they need to operate, thus driving up premiums; and it intends to close Healthcare.gov repeatedly during enrollment. Today’s legally questionable order offers yet another proof-point: He is determined to dismantle the ACA and sabotage the entire healthcare system to score cheap political points and simply declare a victory.

I fight every day in Congress for commonsense policies that keep our country secure and support our men and women in uniform. This year’s NDAA is a compromise that, while far from perfect, takes essential steps to achieve both of those goals.  The bill provides for a well-deserved 2.4 percent pay increase for our servicemembers. This bill will shore up our alliances, deter Russian aggression, and strengthen our efforts to combat terrorism. It requires our military to plan for threats posed by climate change proactively, makes real progress towards a larger and more robust Navy, and maintains important ‘Buy America’ standards that support well-paying jobs. I am pleased that this bill also excludes proposed harmful provisions and discriminatory language that would have targeted transgender servicemembers.  Throughout the NDAA process, I fought for language that would benefit not just our country, but residents of the 4th Congressional District. I am pleased to see that much of the language was included in either the final bill or reports, including requirements that the military actively plan for climate change and sea level rise, language that moves us towards a more muscular Navy, provisions that will help ensure modernization of our public shipyards, and efforts to support appropriate Air Force training range consolidation.  While a compromise, I am pleased to see real progress on so many issues, and I look forward to building on what we have accomplished in this year’s bill.

Secretary DeVos’ decision to hold a private meeting to discuss the "harmful effects" of Obama-era student discipline guidance is deeply troubling. This week in the House Committee on Natural Resources: Democrats, we held a markup on H.R. 3117, Transparency and Honesty in Energy Regulations Act. I voted against this bill because it will ignore critical cost-benefit analyses that we must consider when crafting legislation, especially legislation that will impact climate change. I believe this bill is simply irresponsible. I have introduced a bill that would do the exact opposite as H.R. 3117. My bill, the Pollution Transparency Act, would support the scientifically-developed value for the cost of climate pollution across all federal agencies – ensuring that they accurately weigh the long-term costs of greenhouse gas emissions in their decision-making process. Communities in and around the 4th Congressional District are at-risk for flooding – a direct effect of climate change. I will not support legislation that would harm my constituents.

#ICYMI: Last week, the Republican  majority held a Federal Lands Subcommittee hearing on H.R. 4558, yet another attack on our #publiclands. H.R. 4558 decreases protection for Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument, a change fundamentally at odds with the rationale for creating monuments in the first place. We protect these waters, lands, and sites because they epitomize the awesome power and beauty of nature, the strength of the human spirit, and noble causes that have helped shape our country. I oppose H.R. 4558 and will continue to stand up against any giveaway of our public lands. This bill not only concedes the illegality of the President’s decision two weeks ago but cedes authority to manage the new national park to a management council and leaves formally protected land open to new extracative uses.  This year the President and his colleagues on the other side of the aisle have repeatedly attacked our public lands. We have had enough. Our lands need and richly deserve protection to ensure that future generations will have the same opportunity we enjoy today: the chance to visit, learn, explore, and be inspired by our national treasures.
